questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the OPD due to a one-month history of progressive dyspnoea, generalized weakness, fatigue, and palpitations. He also reports tingling and numbness in both lower limbs. His daughter adds that since his wife's death a year ago, the patient has not been taking care of himself. Blood pressure is 105/50 mmHg and pulse is 104/min. Cardiovascular examination shows a displaced apical impulse at the sixth intercostal space, a third heart sound, and high-volume, collapsing carotid pulses. Bilateral basal crackles, 2+ bilateral pedal edema, and mild hepatomegaly are also present. Neurologic examination shows decreased light touch and vibration sense in the feet, with decreased knee and ankle reflexes bilaterally. Laboratory evaluation shows normal blood counts. Deficiency of which of the following nutrients is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Thiamine

 

The clinical picture of a 58year old man with high-output heart failure (bounding/collapsing pulses, S3, displaced apical impulse, edema, hepatomegaly, basal crackles) plus peripheral neuropathy (distal numbness/tingling, ↓vibration, hyporeflexia) with given history of poor nutrition/self-neglect supports deficiency & normal blood counts argue against megaloblastic anemia (seen in B12 deficiency) is classically suggestive of WET BERIBERI.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ascorbic acid (Vitamin C):

 

  • Deficiency → scurvy: gingival bleeding, perifollicular hemorrhages, corkscrew hairs, impaired wound healing.
  • Does not cause high-output heart failure or the neuropathy pattern described.
  • Edema/hepatomegaly here stem from cardiac failure, not scurvy.

 

Option B. Cobalamin (Vitamin B12):

 

  • Causes subacute combined degeneration: loss of vibration/proprioception, ataxia, +/- paresthesias.
  • Typically accompanied by macrocytic anemia, glossitis; here CBC is normal and cardiac signs are not explained.
  • Does not produce high-output heart failure.

 

Option C. Niacin (Vitamin B3):

 

  • Deficiency → pellagra: the “3 D’s” — dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia (± death).
  • No characteristic high-output cardiac failure or stocking-glove neuropathy as primary features.
  • Clinical picture doesn’t match pellagra.

questions.text: An autopsy was performed on a woman who was reportedly discovered near a village lake. All the following indicate antemortem drowning except
Which of the following tests will be positive in the urine of a patient who has undergone prolonged starvation?

A microbiologist performs a genetic experiment in which cultures of Escherichia coli are treated with a chemical that induces a high frequency of mutations. Individual bacterial colonies are isolated to identify a mutant strain that lacks a specific enzyme involved in DNA replication. This specific enzyme is responsible for removing short fragments of RNA that are base paired to the DNA template. Which of the following enzymes is most likely deficient in this strain of E coli?

questions.text: “Do-It right” for first aid includes all except:
questions.solution: Ans. C. Apply tight torniquet to block arterial circulation of venom.

questions.text: The initial template DNA strand reads as follows: 5' CATTCAATATCGATC 3'. What would be the resulting mRNA sequence after transcription?

A 22-year-old man comes to the office due to recurrent blistering on the back of his hands and forearms for the past several years as shown. The patient usually develops small itchy spots but lately has had large blisters that heal with hyperpigmentation after rupturing. The patient works as a night security guard and has had no exposure to chemicals or animals. He drinks 2-3 cans of beer daily. Which of the following enzymes is most likely deficient in this patient?
Match the following:

Which methods among the following can identify changes in the DNA sequence?

  1. Restriction fragment length analysis
  2. Flow cytometry
  3. Pyrosequencing
  4. FISH
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 and 3

 

Among the listed methods, only Restriction Fragment Length Polymorphism (RFLP) and Pyrosequencing are techniques that can directly detect changes in the DNA sequence.

 

1. Restriction Fragment Length Polymorphism (RFLP):

 

Principle:

 

  • DNA is digested with restriction enzymes that cut at specific base sequences.
  • Mutation or polymorphism that alters a restriction site will change fragment length.
  • These fragments are separated on a gel and visualized by Southern blotting.

 

Therefore:

 

  • RFLP identifies single nucleotide changes or small insertions/deletions that alter restriction sites.
    Detects changes in DNA sequence.

 

2. Flow Cytometry:

 

Principle:

 

  • Detects cell characteristics such as size, granularity, and fluorescent antibody binding.
  • Used for immunophenotyping, cell cycle analysis, and DNA ploidy estimation — not specific sequence changes.
  •  Does not identify DNA sequence alterations.

 

3. Pyrosequencing:

 

Principle:

 

  • A sequencing-by-synthesis method that detects real-time release of pyrophosphate (PPi) when nucleotides are added to a growing DNA strand.
  • It directly determines the order of nucleotides in DNA.
    Accurately detects base substitutions, insertions, and deletions.

 

4. FISH (Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization):

 

Principle:

 

  • Uses fluorescent probes to hybridize to complementary DNA regions on chromosomes.
  • Detects chromosomal abnormalities — deletions, duplications, translocations, aneuploidy.
  • Cannot identify single-base changes or small mutations in DNA sequence.

 

Key Concept:

 

  • DNA sequence changes (point mutations, indels) are detected by RFLP or sequencing techniques (e.g., pyrosequencing, Sanger, NGS)
  • Large structural or chromosomal changes are detected by FISH or karyotyping.

questions.text: 52-year-old man is being evaluated in the emergency department for abdominal pain associated with watery diarrhea. His symptoms have been progressive over the last month. He says that he is depressed and often has difficulty remembering things. The patient has a 20-year history of alcohol abuse. On examination, he appears dishevelled. A pigmented scaly skin rash is present in the malar distribution of his face, neck, and back of his hands as shown. The rash has been present for several months and worsens on exposure to sunlight. Activity of which of the following enzymes would be decreased in the patient because of this deficiency?

Researchers are investigating the relationship between glucose transport proteins and insulin concentration in different types of tissues. Experiments in which cells are taken from various tissue samples and exposed to increasing concentrations of insulin are performed. The number of surface glucose transporters are then measured. The results from 2 cell samples are plotted on the graphs below. Which of the following cell types are most likely represented in cell samples A and B, respectively?
questions.solution: Ans. D. A-Renal tubular cells, B-Skeletal myocytes

questions.text: 24-year-old woman comes to the OPD for a preemployment medical evaluation. The patient has no known medical problems but reports that her skin bruises and scars easily. She says that most of her family members have a very "flexible" body, and her brother works in a circus as a contortionist. Physical examination findings are shown. This patient most likely has an inherited defect in which of the following proteins?

A 50-year-old lady underwent a total abdominal hysterectomy. She came to the hospital after one week with acute pain in the abdomen with features suggestive of perforation. An X-ray showed the following picture. Identify the type of offense for which the surgeon can be held responsible?

All are true about the hexose monophosphate shunt:

  1. Has a role in prevention of methHb
  2. Source of NADPH
  3. Utilizes ribose.
  4. Will be affected in thiamine deficiency.

choices.text: The disease is transmitted in an X-linked recessive fashion.
The mutation is probably located in the 10 kb band.
The patient's brother most likely inherited the mutation.
The patient's son most likely inherited the mutation.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man is found to have an LDL level of 310 mg/dl and a normal serum triglyceride level. His father suffered a myocardial infarction at age 39, and his paternal grandfather died of a heart attack at age 40. The patient's wife has a normal lipid profile. DNA samples are obtained from several family members for genetic analysis. Southern blotting of restriction fragments from a region containing the LDL receptor gene shows the following pattern. Identify the correct statement:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The patient's son most likely inherited the mutation.

 

Familial hypercholesterolemia (LDLR defect) is autosomal dominant. On the Southern blot, the 8-kb fragment cosegregates with affected individuals in the paternal line: the father (affected) has 10 & 8 kb; the patient (affected) has 12 & 8 kb—the shared allele is 8 kb. The son shows 20 & 8 kb; since the wife has 20 & 10 kb, the son must have received 20 kb from mother and 8 kb from father → he most likely carries the mutant 8-kb–linked allele.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The disease is transmitted in an X-linked recessive fashion: Familial hypercholesterolemia due to LDL receptor mutations is autosomal dominant, not X-linked. Affected males and females are seen across generations; father-to-son transmission is compatible with AD, not X-linked.

 

Option B. The mutation is probably located in the 10-kb band: The affected father (10 & 8) and affected patient (12 & 8) share the 8-kb band, not the 10-kb. The 10-kb fragment is present in unaffected relatives (wife, brother), so it does not co-segregate with disease.

 

Option C. The patient’s brother most likely inherited the mutation: The brother shows 20 & 10 kb fragments and lacks the 8-kb fragment that tracks with disease in the paternal line; thus he most likely did not inherit the mutant allele.

  2. Burn injuries - occur due to flame released during the firing

15-year-old boy is found to have unexplained erythrocytosis on routine laboratory analysis. Evaluation of his immediate family shows that his father and sister also have elevated red cell levels. Genetic sequencing of the 13-globin gene is performed in the affected family members. The results showed a single base substitution at amino acid position 82 that replaces the normal lysine residue with methionine. Further analysis shows that this amino acid replacement impairs the ionic interaction between the 13-subunit and 2,3-bisphosphoglycerate. As a result of this mutation, the patient's haemoglobin will be most like which of the following haemoglobin types?

A group of investigators are studying the regulation of catecholamine synthesis in response to severe stress. In the experiments, subject rats are randomly assigned to either an experimental or a control group. The experimental rats undergo resection of the pituitary gland, and the control rats undergo craniotomy without pituitary resection. The experimental animals are subsequently found to have decreased production of epinephrine by the adrenal medulla and cortisol from the adrenal cortex compared with the control animals. Decrease d activity of which of the following enzymes is most likely responsible for the lower epinephrine in the experimental animals?

Amar was tried in a court in the case of Akbar's murder in the park. Anthony appeared in court and salt that he saw Amar with an axe in his hand while passing the park. What is this evidence known as?

A 6-year-old African American male is brought to your office for a routine check-up. His mother remarks that he often seems uninterested in playing with his peers and appears to "run out of breath quickly." His medical records reveal that he has missed several pediatric vaccinations and has been hospitalized twice, once with a "chest infection" and once with abdominal pain. The patient mentions to you that occasionally his "bones hurt." Which of the following protein changes most likely accounts for this patient's condition?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Valine substitution for glutamic acid

A specific human cell type is incubated in glucose-rich media. Intracellular levels of glucose metabolizing enzymes, intermediate products, and generated ATP are measured. In these cells, glycolysis of a single glucose molecule always yields pyruvate but sometimes generates no net ATP. Which of the following cells is most likely being studied in this experiment?

choices.text: Restriction enzyme susceptibility sites within the target exon.
The amino acid sequence of the abnormal BRCA 1 protein.
The complete nucleotide sequence of the target exon.
The nucleotide sequence of the regions flanking the target exon.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the OPD after her sister was diagnosed with breast cancer. Her sister was found to have a multiple base pair insertion affecting exon 11 of the BRCA 1 gene that leads to a frameshift mutation. A screening test to evaluate for a similar insertion mutation in the patient's BRCA 1 gene is performed. The test uses polymerase chain reaction (PCR) to amplify the target exon and gel electrophoresis to assess the size of the exon compared to the wild-type allele. Which of the following must be known to perform the amplification part of this analysis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The nucleotide sequence of the regions flanking the target exon.

 

This question describes a PCR-based mutation detection test — used to check for an insertion in exon 11 of the BRCA1 gene by amplifying that exon and comparing PCR product size on a gel.

To successfully amplify a specific DNA region by Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR), you need to design primers that bind to known sequences flanking (on both sides of) the target DNA segment.

 

Stepwise Concept:

1. Principle of PCR:

  • PCR amplifies a specific DNA fragment between two known sequences.
  • It requires:
    • DNA template
    • Two primers (forward and reverse)
    • DNA polymerase (Taq polymerase)
    • Nucleotides (dNTPs)
    • Thermal cycling (denaturation, annealing, extension)

 

2. Primers bind to known sequences:

  • To amplify exon 11, primers must anneal to the intronic or adjacent regions flanking exon 11 (the regions immediately upstream and downstream).
  • Once primers bind, polymerase can copy the DNA in between → product length reflects insertion or deletion mutations.

 

Other Options:

questions.text: Match the following appearances with the timeline:
questions.solution: Ans. A. A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital with a diagnosis of acute appendicitis. The patient had no food, only sips of water since 30hours. Blood pressure is 115/72 mm Hg and pulse is 106/ min. Mucous membranes are dry and there is tenderness in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen. Laboratory evaluation shows mild leucocytosis, normal serum electrolytes, borderline low serum glucose levels, and moderate ketones in the urine. Based on the evaluation, it is suspected that this patient is utilizing ketone bodies as a significant reserve of energy. Which of the following tissues cannot use this energy source?

A 34-year-old previously healthy man comes to the emergency department due to a 3-hour history of chest pain, diaphoresis, and dyspnea. He does not smoke, exercises regularly, and eats a balanced diet. His father died at age 56 from a myocardial infarction. His blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg and pulse is 110/min and regular. ECG shows ST elevation in the anterolateral leads. Coronary angiogram reveals proximal left anterior descending artery stenosis and thrombosis, which is treated with angioplasty and stent.

 

Placement. Laboratory results are as follows:

 

Total cholesterol: 160 mg/dL

 

Low-density lipoprotein: 90 mg/dL

 

Glucose, serum : 98 mg/dL

 

Homocysteine, plasma : 21.5 µmol/L (normal: 4-14 µmol/ L)

 

Further testing reveals a homozygous mutation in the methylene tetrahydrofolate reductase gene that leads to decreased enzymatic activity. Due to this defect, the patient most likely has impairment converting homocysteine to which of the following?
What is the cause of the lesion shown in the image below?
Match the following weapons with the possible injuries caused by them:
questions.solution: Ans. A. A-4, B-3, C-1, D-2

questions.text: In an animal experiment, mice proerythroblasts are cultured in 2 different growth media; the first medium is folate deficient, whereas the second (control) is supplemented with folic acid. Both media contain high concentrations of erythropoietin. Over 48 hours, cells in the control media proliferate and differentiate into reticulocytes, whereas in the folate-deficient media, cell proliferation is minimal, with most cells undergoing apoptosis. In another experiment, a substance is added to the folate-deficient media, which prevents apoptosis and permits proliferation of the proerythroblasts. Which of the following is the most likely substance added to the growth medium?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Thymidine

 

This experiment demonstrates the role of folate in DNA synthesis, particularly in the formation of thymidine (dTMP) — a nucleotide essential for DNA replication.

 

When folate is deficient, thymidine production decreases, causing defective DNA synthesis, cell cycle arrest, and apoptosis, especially in rapidly dividing cells like proerythroblasts.

 

Stepwise Biochemical Mechanism:

 

1. Normal Folate Function:

 

Folate → reduced to tetrahydrofolate (THF) → converted to 5,10-methylene THF, which acts as a methyl donor in this reaction:

 

dUMP + 5,10"-methylene THF" → dTMP + DHF

 


 

Enzyme: Thymidylate synthase


Product: dTMP (thymidine monophosphate) — used for DNA synthesis

 

Thus, folate is essential for synthesis of thymidine (and hence, DNA).

 

2. In Folate Deficiency:

 

  • ↓ 5,10-methylene THF
  • ↓ dTMP (thymidine) formation
  • Uracil gets misincorporated into DNA instead of thymidine
  • → DNA breaks → apoptosis

 

Most affected cells: Rapidly dividing cells (bone marrow, GI mucosa, embryonic cells).

 

3. Addition of Thymidine:

 

If exogenous thymidine is added, it bypasses the folate-dependent step, restoring DNA synthesis and allowing cell proliferation to continue despite folate deficiency.

 

Therefore, adding thymidine rescues cells from death in folate-deficient media.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cobalamin (Vitamin B12): B12 deficiency also impairs folate metabolism (via methyl trap), but adding B12 cannot directly supply thymidine.

 

Option B. Cytosine: Pyrimidine base but not used directly in DNA synthesis; does not bypass thymidylate synthase blockade.

 

Option C. Homocysteine: Accumulates in folate/B12 deficiency; supplementing it has no role in DNA synthesis.

questions.text: Match the following with the respective ages of fusion:
questions.solution: Ans. B) A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3

Past medical history is notable for hypertension, for which the patient takes a calcium channel blocker, and hypertriglyceridemia, which is treated with a fibrate. She undergoes a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, with multiple stones noted in the contents of the gallbladder. Decreased activity of which of the following enzymes would most likely have contributed to this patient's condition?

Choose the right sequence of steps in the conversion of cholesterol to testosterone?

  1. 17-alpha hydroxylase
  2. 20, 22-desmolase
  3. 17, 20-lyase

There are two repressors for one inducer.

questions.text: E. coli colonies grown on a lactose-containing medium up-regulate the production of the enzymes 13-galactosidase and galactoside permease.  Which of the following best explains the synchronous production of both enzymes in response to lactose?
questions.solution: Ans. D. There is one mRNA coding for both enzymes.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy with developmental delay is brought to the OPD due to difficulty "seeing the board" at school. Examination shows a tall, thin habitus with elongated limbs. Funduscopy shows bilateral lens subluxation. Four years later, the patient dies suddenly of a massive cerebrovascular accident. Autopsy shows middle cerebral artery thrombosis and old renal infarcts. His parents wish to know if anything could have been done to have prevented his death. Which of the following would have been the most appropriate supplementation for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pyridoxine 

 

This 5-year-old boy has features suggestive of Homocystinuria due to Cystathionine β-synthase deficiency, a condition that leads to elevated homocysteine levels and predisposes to thromboembolic events (the cause of death in this case).

 

Stepwise Diagnostic Reasoning:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ascorbic acid (Vitamin C):

 

  • Cofactor in collagen hydroxylation, not related to homocysteine metabolism.
  • Deficiency → scurvy (bleeding gums, poor wound healing).

 

Option B. Carnitine:

 

  • Involved in transport of long-chain fatty acids into mitochondria for β-oxidation.
  • Deficiency → hypoketotic hypoglycemia and muscle weakness.

 

Option D. Thiamine (Vitamin B1):

 

  • Cofactor for pyruvate dehydrogenase, α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, and transketolase.
  • Deficiency → beriberi or Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

questions.text: A doctor used the same needle used in a patient with HIV to inject in another patient. The latter patient on testing found to be infected with HIV. The doctor is punishable for this negligence according to which section of Indian Penal Code?

A research scientist is studying biochemical reactions that take place in the liver. He cultures hepatocytes in a growth media enriched with glutamate labelled with nitrogen isotopes. After some time, he finds that the nitrogen isotopes are transferred to oxaloacetate, forming aspartate in the process. Which of the following substances is most likely involved in this reaction?

  1. Expression of protein and lysis of bacterial cell
  2. Incorporation of genes into bacteria
  3. SDS PAGE
  4. Protein elution
  5. Hybridization

A 5-day-old term newborn is brought to the emergency department for multiple episodes of emesis. The breastfed infant has been having fewer wet diapers over the last 2 days. Vital signs show tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypotension. Physical examination shows an icteric, lethargic baby with a sunken fontanelle, dry mucous membranes, and hepatomegaly. A blood culture is drawn, and empiric antibiotics are initiated. Serum studies show hypoglycemia and elevated transaminases. The ammonia level is normal. Preliminary results from arterial blood culture show gram-negative rods. The infant is placed on a special formula and gradually improves over the next few days. Which of the following steps in metabolism is most likely impaired in this patient?
Identify the gestational age of the fetus if the Crown Rump Length is 21 cm, length of lower limb is 10 cm, gestational age of the fetus will be:

Identify the correct statements:

  1. Normally LDH 2 is predominant in the blood and LDH 1 is predominant in the heart. During a myocardial infarction, due to damage to the cardiac tissue, LDH 1 is released into the bloodstream resulting in a high LDH1:LDH2 ratio called flipped LDH ratio. 
  2. Consumption of polished rice leads to thiamine deficiency which leads to defective transketolase activity.
  3. Zinc deficiency presents with erythematous scaly patches in the perioral region, mucosal ulcers, and impaired epithelial wound healing.
  4. Copper deficiency presents with pigmentation of hair, hypothermia, degenerative changes in aortic elastin, osteopenia.

A 2-year-old boy is being evaluated for failure to thrive and developmental delay. His past medical history is significant for recurrent ear infections since age 6 months. Physical examination shows coarse facial features, corneal clouding, hepatosplenomegaly, and restricted joint mobility. Mass spectrometry analysis is performed on cultured fibroblasts and reveals deficient phosphorylation of mannose residues on certain glycoproteins in the Golgi apparatus. Normally, these proteins are most likely to be transported to which of the following cellular locations?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lysosome

 

This child presents with failure to thrive, developmental delay, coarse facial features, corneal clouding, and hepatosplenomegaly — the classic presentation of I-cell disease (Inclusion-cell disease), also known as Mucolipidosis type II.

 

Underlying Defect:

 

  • Defective enzyme: N-acetylglucosaminyl-1-phosphotransferase
  • Location of defect: Golgi apparatus
  • Normal function of this enzyme:
    • Adds phosphate group to mannose residues on lysosomal enzymes → forms mannose-6-phosphate (M6P) tag.
    • The M6P tag is a “postal code” that directs enzymes to lysosomes.

 

Pathogenesis:

 

  1. In I-cell disease, defective phosphotransferase enzyme = no M6P tagging.
  2. Lysosomal enzymes are not recognized by lysosomal receptors.
  3. These enzymes are instead secreted into the extracellular space rather than being delivered to lysosomes.
  4. As a result, lysosomes lack necessary degradative enzymes.
  5. Undigested macromolecules accumulate → formation of inclusion bodies in cells → organomegaly and coarse features.

 

Normal Destination of These Proteins:

 

  • Normally, M6P-tagged hydrolase enzymes are targeted from the Golgi → lysosomes, where they degrade complex substrates.
  • Without tagging, they end up outside the cell instead of their proper destination.
    Hence, under normal conditions, these glycoproteins are destined for the lysosome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extracellular space:

 

  • In I-cell disease, defective tagging causes enzymes to be misdirected here.
  • However, normally these proteins should go to lysosomes, not extracellular space.

 

Option C. Mitochondria & Option D. Nucleus: Are unrelated to M6P tagging.

choices.text: Orbicularis oculi, facial muscles, thorax, upper limb
Orbicularis oculi, neck, facial muscles, upper limb, thorax
Neck, muscles of eyelid, upper limb, thorax
Neck, muscles of eyelid, facial muscles, thorax, upper limb

questions.text: From early to late, which muscles develop rigor mortis?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Orbicularis oculi, neck, facial muscles, upper limb, thorax

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy with growth retardation, microcephaly, sun-sensitive skin rash, and recurrent infections is being evaluated for a possible inherited genetic defect. The patient is the second-born child of a first cousin marriage. His parents and siblings are healthy, but 2 of his maternal cousins have similar signs and symptoms. Genetic analysis of the patient reveals a defect in the BLM gene that codes for DNA helicase. Which of the following is the most likely site of action of this enzyme in the DNA replication fork shown?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B

 

The diagram depicts a DNA replication fork, and the enzyme affected in this patient’s condition—Bloom syndrome—is DNA helicase. The helicase enzyme functions at the replication fork (site B), where it unwinds the double-stranded DNA into two single strands to allow the DNA polymerases to synthesize new strands.

 

A defect in the BLM gene (Bloom syndrome gene) leads to impaired helicase activity, resulting in defective DNA replication, increased chromosomal breakage, and genomic instability. Clinically, this presents as growth retardation, sun-sensitive rash, immunodeficiency, and predisposition to cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Represents DNA gyrase (topoisomerase II): this enzyme relieves supercoiling ahead of the replication fork, not unwinding the strands.

 

Option C. Represents single-stranded DNA binding proteins (SSBs): they stabilize unwound DNA and prevent reannealing, but do not separate strands.

 

Option D. Represents primase: which synthesizes short RNA primers for DNA polymerase to initiate synthesis on the lagging strand.

 

Other labelled points:

 

E: DNA Polymerase III: This enzyme is responsible for synthesizing new DNA strands by adding nucleotides to the 3′ end of the growing chain.

 

F: DNA Ligase: After the RNA primers between Okazaki fragments are removed and replaced with DNA (by DNA polymerase I), DNA ligase seals the nicks between adjacent DNA fragments by forming Phosphodiesterase bonds.

questions.solution: Ans. A. In Africanoids the cusps of molars are wide and deep with shovel shaped cusps in incisors.

A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with fever, vomiting, and sleepiness. Since the newborn period, the parents say that the patient has had multiple similar episodes.  Lab results revealed increased blood ammonia levels during these episodes and markedly increased orotic acid excretion in the urine. Physical examination shows a tachypneic boy who is unresponsive to all stimuli. Which of the following enzymes is most likely to be deficient in this patient?

A 4-month-old boy is being evaluated for a hereditary metabolic disorder after presenting with failure to thrive and developmental delay. He had several seizures during the neonatal period. Physical examination reveals an abnormal head shape with a large anterior fontanelle and widely splayed cranial sutures. Profound hypotonia and hepatomegaly are also noted. Biochemical studies show elevated levels of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFAs) and phytanic acid. Cultured skin fibroblasts show impaired ability to oxidize VLCFAs. This patient's condition is best explained by dysfunction of which of the following cellular structures?

An 18-year-old man comes to the office due to a progressive skin rash over the past year. He also has a long-standing history of an intermittent burning sensation in his palms and soles that is exacerbated by stress and fatigue. The burning sensation is particularly severe after exercise, during which the patient notes that he sweats minimally. Laboratory evaluation reveals an undetectable level of a-galactosidase A. Which of the following conditions is this patient at greatest risk for developing?

A child before playing consumed fruit from the garden. After some time, he developed a high fever, confusion, photophobia, and unable to urinate. What are the likely causative agent and the appropriate antidote used in this case?

Identify the correct statements:

 

  1. Phosphatidylcholine is most abundant phospholipid in surfactant.
  2. Cardiolipin is deficient in Barth syndrome.
  3. Ceramidase deficiency is associated with Fabry disease.
  4. Triglycerides are not amphipathic.

A 5-month-old boy is brought to the office due to poor feeding. His mother says that he has difficulty holding his head up while breastfeeding and his suckling seems weaker than it used to be. Physical examination shows hepatomegaly and hypotonia in all 4 limbs. Cardiac auscultation reveals a gallop rhythm, and chest x-ray shows severe cardiomegaly. Muscle biopsy shows enlarged lysosomes containing periodic acid-Schiff (PAS}-positive material. Which of the following enzymes is most likely deficient in this patient?
The method of autopsy carried out en masse to remove from tongue to prostate is?
Which of the following is not a substrate for glucose formation?

45-year-old man is referred to an endocrinologist for newly diagnosed diabetes mellitus. A week ago, his primary care physician noted an elevated fasting serum glucose level. The endocrinologist discusses the different treatment options available, including oral and injectable medications. He recommends treatment with a medication that alters glucose metabolism within the liver by increasing the concentration of fructose 2,6-bisphosphate within hepatocytes. Which of the following conversions will be inhibited by high intracellular concentrations of this metabolite?

A 10-year-old male child came to the casualty with difficulty in walking and pain in the perianal region. On subjecting the specimen from the perianal region to a test, following appearance is seen under the microscope. What is the test done?

Which of the following statements are true regarding mitochondrial DNA?

  1. Higher rate of mutations as compared to the nuclear genome.
  2. Double-stranded circular DNA with about 16,000 base pairs
  3. Constitutes 1% of cellular DNA.
  4. Encodes for 20% of electron transport chain proteins.

A research scientist studying the metabolic pathways that contribute to obesity, feeds experimental animals a high-carbohydrate, high-protein diet for a prolonged period. A sample of liver tissue is then obtained from the animals, and the activity of various enzymes involved in fatty acid metabolism is measured and recorded. It is determined that beta-oxidation of fatty acids is inhibited within these cells because of the diet. An increase in which of the following substances is most likely responsible for the observed effect?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Malonyl-CoA

 

This question tests understanding of fatty acid metabolism regulation — particularly the reciprocal control between fatty acid synthesis and β-oxidation in the liver.

 

The key regulatory molecule connecting both pathways is malonyl-CoA, an intermediate in fatty acid synthesis that inhibits fatty acid oxidation.

 

Concepts of metabolism associated:

 

1. High-carbohydrate, high-protein diet → ↑ Insulin

 

  • Increased insulin stimulates lipogenesis (fat synthesis) in the liver.
  • The high carbohydrate intake provides acetyl-CoA, which enters fatty acid synthesis via the enzyme acetyl-CoA carboxylase (ACC).

 

2. Malonyl-CoA: a Key Regulator

 

  • Malonyl-CoA is the first committed intermediate of fatty acid synthesis.
  • It serves two roles:
    1. Substrate for fatty acid synthesis.
    2. Allosteric inhibitor of carnitine palmitoyl transferase I (CPT I), the enzyme that transfers fatty acids into the mitochondrial matrix for β-oxidation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acetoacetate: Acetoacetate is a ketone body formed during periods of fasting or increased fatty acid oxidation.
An increase in acetoacetate indicates enhanced β-oxidation activity, not inhibition of it.

 

Option B. Carnitine: Carnitine functions as a transport molecule that carries long-chain fatty acids into the mitochondrial matrix for oxidation.
Higher carnitine levels would promote fatty acid oxidation, not block it.

 

Option C. Citrate: Citrate accumulates when there is excess energy and moves from mitochondria to the cytosol to activate acetyl-CoA carboxylase, promoting fatty acid synthesis.


Although it encourages lipid synthesis indirectly, it does not directly inhibit β-oxidation.


Its inhibitory effect occurs only through its role in increasing malonyl-CoA formation.

The patient has yellowish skin nodules over the palmar creases that have been increasing in size and number over the past several years. He also has small clusters of yellow papules on his elbows, knees, and buttocks. His father died of a myocardial infarction at age 56. lmmunoblot analysis suggests a lack of ApoE3 and Apo E4 in his circulating lipoproteins. questions.text: A 30-year-old individual diagnosed with schizophrenia commits an act that would otherwise be considered a criminal offense. The act was committed during a period of acute psychotic episode. The individual's medical history indicates sporadic adherence to rescribed antipsychotic medication. The prosecution has charged the individual with the offense. Based on the provided information, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the applicability of Section 84 of IPC in this case?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Section 84 applies as the offence was committed during psychotic episode, regardless of medication adherence.

Laboratory studies show hypoglycemia and ketoacidosis. A liver biopsy shows hepatic fibrosis without fat accumulation. Further analysis reveals abundant quantities of a multibranched polysaccharide with abnormally short outer chains within the cytosol of the hepatocytes. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 6-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of recent onset of vomiting, irritability, and jaundice. The infant was born at term and had been healthy until the onset of these symptoms. All his vaccinations are up to date. He had been breast-fed exclusively until 1 week ago, when cereals and fruit juices were introduced into his diet. Further evaluation reveals hepatomegaly and abnormal liver function tests. Which of the following enzymes is most likely to be deficient in this patient?
Match the following:

A 35-year-old female is hospitalized with headaches and vomiting. She has a long history of psychiatric illness and is known to practice eccentric. dietary habits. Physical findings include papilledema, dry skin, and hepatosplenomegaly. Head CT scan is ordered immediately but is negative for intracranial mass. Which of the following is a likely cause of this patient's condition?

A 14-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to excessive urination and thirst. He has lost 4.5 kg in the last 3 weeks. Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes. Laboratory studies reveal blood glucose of 455 mg/dl, normal anion gap, and HbA1c of 11.3%. The patient is diagnosed with type 1 diabetes, and treatment with insulin is initiated. In addition to lowering blood glucose, insulin increases glycogen synthesis in hepatocytes. Activation of which of the following molecules most likely promotes this metabolic effect?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Protein phosphatase

 

In hepatocytes, insulin promotes glycogen synthesis primarily by activating protein phosphatase, which removes phosphate groups (dephosphorylates) key enzymes in glycogen metabolism.

 

Mechanism:

 

  1. Insulin binds to its tyrosine kinase receptor on hepatocytes.
  2. This triggers a signaling cascade that activates protein phosphatase-1.
  3. Protein phosphatase-1 then:
    • Dephosphorylates glycogen synthase → activates it → ↑ glycogen synthesis.
    • Dephosphorylates glycogen phosphorylase → inactivates it → ↓ glycogen breakdown.

 

Hence, the overall effect is increased glycogen storage in the liver.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Janus kinase (JAK): JAK is a tyrosine kinase involved in the JAK-STAT signaling pathway, which mediates the effects of cytokines and some growth hormones such as erythropoietin and growth hormone.


It is not involved in insulin signaling, which occurs through a receptor tyrosine kinase–PI3K pathway.

 

Option B. Phospholipase C: Phospholipase C is activated by Gq protein–coupled receptors, leading to the production of IP₃ and DAG and increased intracellular calcium.


This pathway is characteristic of hormones like vasopressin and angiotensin II, not insulin.

 

Option D. Protein phosphatase: Protein phosphatase is activated by insulin signaling through the PI3K-Akt pathway.


It dephosphorylates glycogen synthase, activating it, and inactivates glycogen phosphorylase, promoting glycogen synthesis.


Therefore, activation of protein phosphatase mediates insulin’s anabolic effect on hepatocytes.

Leading Questions are permitted in all except:

Which of the following enzymes use selenocysteine?

  2. Glutathione synthase

  4. Thioredoxin reductase

A pharmaceutical corporation investigating new therapeutic agents for treatment of Burkitt lymphoma synthesizes a double-stranded RNA molecule that is 21 base pairs in length. The RNA molecule has a base pair sequence that is complementary to a region of mRNA encoding c-Myc. Introduction of the RNA molecule into tumor cells results in a significant reduction in cell growth. Western blot analysis of equivalent numbers of treated and untreated cells is shown below. Which of the following processes was most likely directly interrupted in the cells exposed to the RNA molecule?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) mRNA translation 

 

The Western blot shows that c-Myc protein levels are markedly decreased in treated cells compared with untreated ones.


This indicates that the therapy specifically reduced c-Myc protein synthesis — not DNA or mRNA production, which is a direct consequence of alteration in mRNA translation.

 

Mechanism of Action:

 

  • The double-stranded 21-base-pair RNA introduced into tumor cells represents small interfering RNA (siRNA).
  • siRNA functions via the RNA interference (RNAi) pathway:
  1. siRNA is incorporated into the RNA-induced silencing complex (RISC).
  2. The antisense strand of siRNA binds complementary mRNA (in this case, c-myc mRNA).
  3. RISC then cleaves or degrades the target mRNA, preventing its translation into protein.

 

Thus, translation of c-myc mRNA → c-Myc protein is blocked directly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DNA replication:

 

  • Involves DNA polymerase copying DNA before cell division.
  • siRNA acts on mRNA, not DNA, so replication remains unaffected.

 

Option B. DNA transcription:

 

  • Transcription is synthesis of mRNA from DNA via RNA polymerase II.
  • siRNA acts after mRNA is formed—by degrading existing mRNA, not blocking its transcription, which occurs before translation.

 

Option D. Proteasome activity:

 

  • Proteasomes degrade already synthesized proteins tagged by ubiquitin.
  • siRNA doesn’t alter proteasomal degradation.

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy is brought to the OPD by his mother out of concern that he is not developing normally.
